column4: okay.. I have a question... is it actually possible to run ubuntu(installation or livecd)  via a usb stick?
I've heard of DSL :P
it doesn't have enough features for me :(
o.O? how? :P
I ask this because, my bro has a crap(and I mean CRAP) laptop, it's a pent3 750mhz with 64megs of ram(I think)... he said he wants to try out linux, but the cd drive is fucked... it doesn't open x_X;
spec - I don't actually have a usb stick, yet :P
spec - his ethernet adapter doesn't work lol
my bro's laptop currently runs WinXP.. it's snailspeed -.-
spec - correct.. tricky lol
xubuntu? I thought the rumour of it being faster than ubuntu was not proven?
xubuntu uses xfce, which is a lot more lightweight than gnome, really/
not necessarily, you could have a 64-bit browser that can handle 32-bit plugins (i.e. Konqueror)
you still couldn't use it on Ubuntu without a chroot though; no BiArch-compatible.
I have no idea what you're talking about :P
AMD64s can perfectly well execute 32-bit binaries (it's backward-compatible), but the Ubuntu package management system isn't set to be BiArch-compatible unfortunately.
some talk of getting it to be for Edgy, but we'll have to wait and see.

it's like another Ubuntu installation on your computer. It's often used for building packages (since you can get a completely new environment) or for distributions like Ubuntu which aren't BiArch so you can have 32bit programs
we like to call that configurability and extensibility :)
hm, I wouldn't say it had "junk" that way. And anyway, with regard to applications, GTK/GNOME are just as guilty of having several applications to do the same thing 8)
really?
for me, it is :P
